sourceDesc.p: M.R. James, Descriptive Catalogue of the Manuscripts in the Library of Corpus Christi College, Cambridge 1912

projectDesc.p: The James Catalogue was digitized then marked up following the TEI P5 Guidelines. The customized model was provided by Giuliano Di Bacco, stored in an ODD file (parkerweb.xml): the latter was written by GDB using ROMA vers. 2.x, with manual adaptations. The ODD file is used as a source to compile the actual schema used to validate the xml: it is advisable to compile it in RelaxNG sintax (parkerweb.rnc) through ROMA.

msDesc.head: Old English Religious and Legal Texts, many by Wulfstan
Wulfstani Homiliae. Leges, Canones, etc.
msDesc.p: Vellum, 278 165 , 11 x 6.5, ff. 2 + 73 + 16 + 42 + 1, three main volumes. Cent. xi, in various good hands.
Collation: 2 flyleaves, 18-58 (wants 1) 68-98 102 | 114 124 (wants 4) 138 (+ 1?: two leaves misbound) | A8-E8 F2 | 1 flyleaf.
Wanley refers the book to Worcester or to a house dependent thereon.
This is the principal source of the Homilies of Wulfstan, collected and published by Professor A. S. Napier (Wulfstan, 1883), to which reference will be made here.
On the flyleaves is the beginning of a table by Whelock. (ff. iv - iiv, pp. 263 - 264)

On p. 1 a heading (xvi) Miscellanea quaedam Saxonice, vol. 284, and a Parkerian table of contents.
The text of this page has been washed out, except for 3 lines at the bottom.

head.title: Pars libri cujusdam ut videtur ritualis de diversis diebus festis in usum cujusdam monasterii

msItem.ab: See Emil Feiler Benediktiner Offizium in Anglistische Forschungen 4 (1901), Zupitza in Herrig's Archiv 84, 1, Miss Bateson in Eng. Hist. Rev. 1894, p. 707
The text is in a rather pointed hand, 41 lines to a page: ending p. 7
msItem.explicit: orationes þe æfter fyligeað 7 cƿeðe á þæt forme

head.title: Anonymous homily Adam se ærest man

msItem.ab: On p. 8 begins a clear round hand, 41 lines to a page, which apparently continues to p. 145 (Arts. 2-83). Titles are written in good capital letters

head.title: On the Resting Places of English Saints
her cyð ymbe þa halgan þeon angel cynne restað

msItem.ab: Ed. by Liebermann, Die Heiligen Englands, 1889: see p. xiv. This is MS. C in his edition. It contains both parts of the tract

head.title: On the Resting Places of English Saints (continued)
her onginneð setgam be godes scm ðe on engla lande ærest reston

msItem.ab: Ed. by Liebermann, Die Heiligen Englands, 1889: see p. xiv. This is MS. C in his edition. It contains both parts of the tract
The last three lines, at top of p. 151, seem to me to be in another hand

head.title: her cydde god ælmihtig his mildheortnisse þe he abrahame behet 7 iosepe 7 abrahames ofspringe

ab.quote: Haec tractatio de Josepho patriarcha est pars versionis seu potius excerptorum Ælfrici ex libro Geneseos scil. cap. XXXVII usque ad cap. XLVII, vers. 18

ab.handNote: Another hand, slightly sloping: very clear

msItem.ab: See Wülcker, A.-S. Litt. 469, 2. Körner Einleitung in Angelsächs. II 8. Grein, Prosabibliothek, p. 80
Ending imperfectly
msItem.explicit: ne feoh ne orf 7 þu sylf ƿard

head.title: The Judgement Day II, Old English poem translated from Bede's De die iudicii
Versus Bedae presbiteri de die judicii Saxonicis versibus redditi

msItem.ab: Nos. 87, 88 are in the same hand as no. 1
These poems were edited by Dr Lumby for the E. E. T. S. in 1876 in a volume entitled Be domes dæge: also in Grein-Wülcker
They consist of
A version of the poem ascribed to Bede and Alcuin de die iudicii (Inter florigeras)
A supplementary exhortation called by Lumby Lar

head.title: An Exhortation to Christian Living (Old English poem)
A summons to prayer (Old English and Latin macaronic poem)
Oratio poetica ex adonicis (quales facere potuerunt) versibus partim Latinis partim Saxonicis

msItem.ab: An Oratio Poetica

head.title: The Lord's Prayer II (Old English poem)

msItem.ab: Paraphrases of the Lord's Prayer and the Gloria Patri
d, e are in a different hand from the rest
Paraphrases of the Lord's Prayer and the Gloria Patri
d, e are in a different hand from the rest

head.title: Forms of absolution and confession, etc.

msItem.ab: The hand of this is very large and round. The Confiteor in full, followed (p. 171) by Preces and Absolutio: on pp. 173-174 a form pro femina. Two leaves (pp. 171-174) are misplaced. They precede, instead of following, pp. 175, 176
pp. 177, 178 are blank

msItem.head: Theodulf of Orléans, Capitula

head.title: Canones Numero XLV in usum clericorum

msItem.ab: Here begins another volume in a larger hand than appears elsewhere (save in no. 91, which is larger still): 27 lines to a page
The contents of items 92 - 94 are the Canons of Theodulf, the original of the Ecclesiastical Institutes in Thorpe, p. 469
Ending
The Anglo-Saxon version contained in Thorpe, pp. 466-469, follows on pp. 222-230

msItem.head: Theodulf of Orléans, Capitula (Old English version)
msItem.ab: On pp. 231-269 is the A.-S. version contained in Thorpe, pp. 469-488

msItem.head: Usuard, Martyrologium (preface)

head.title: Epistola Oswardi monachi ad Karolum regem

ab.handNote: In a hand of cent. xii early

msItem.incipit: Domino Regum piissimo karolo osuuardus sacerdos

msItem.head: Usuard, Martyrologium (extract from Introduction)
msItem.ab: (10 lines only) ending
It is the Prologue to Usuard's Martyrology (P. L. CXXIII 453): collated by Hampe (Neues Archiv, XXII 669)
